Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Behavioral Biometrics for Preventing and Detecting Digital Frauds
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project empowers eCommerce owners, digital bankers, and healthcare service providers alike with a behavioral biometrics-based solution and service to more effectively prevent and detect fraudulent activities after account takeovers. The demand for online fraud detection is strong due to the continuing growth of eCommerce, banking, and healthcare, and the rising of account takeovers and related fraud. Moreover, industrialized fraudsters can weaponize a vulnerability in matters of minutes once a breach is exploited, and exponentially scale it to cause high financial loss for organizations and more importantly, undermine their credibility and reputation. Unfortunately, currently organizations rely on dedicated fraud detection teams to perform manual reviews to handle fraudulent cases, which is both time consuming and costly; they also rely on simplified, rules-based approaches for fraud detection, which unfortunately result in a high number of false positives and ultimately hurt customer experience and retention. Leveraging behavioral biometrics collected unobtrusively when a user conducts online business, the proposed innovation will provide additional user authentication and thus help businesses prevent and detect more fraudulent activities in a more reliable and effective fashion.<br/><br/>This I-Corps project seeks to perform customer discovery of business entities such as eCommerce owners, digital bankers, and healthcare service providers, to identify the most valuable product parameters before formulating the proposed innovation into a market-ready product. A common problem is that these businesses are all obligated to safeguard user data and online transactions but are plagued by the continuous stream of account takeover attacks on their IT systems and the ensuing financial fraud. The proposed innovation produces a software solution and service that provides additional capability of user authentication to help businesses to significantly reduce such fraud despite of account takeovers. This innovation distinguishes between users by leveraging behavioral biometrics that unobtrusively capture a user's unique computing behavior, such as how they type on keyboards or how they move the mouse. The proposed software product packages state-of-the-art authentication algorithms so that existing business applications can access them via API calls. In addition, the end user is provided with full control over their own biometric data for privacy protection. The technological implementation of the proposed approach uses JavaScript in the web browsers and integrates with legacy applications at the server end.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to empower government, banks, eCommerce, and healthcare providers alike with novel behavioral biometrics-based authentication to more effectively prevent and detect fraudulent online activities. A common problem across organizations is that they are all legally obligated to safeguard user data and online transactions but plagued by the continuous stream of account takeover attacks on their IT systems and the ensuing fraud. Leveraging behavioral biometrics collected unobtrusively when a user conducts online transactions, the proposed innovation will provide additional user authentication, but in a much more usable fashion, to help organizations defeat fraudulent activities and reduce fraud.

This I-Corps project seeks to perform customer discovery to determine the viability of, and identify the appropriate parameters for formulating the proposed innovation into, a market-ready product. The proposed innovation will be delivered as software products and services that will significantly reduce online fraud. This innovation distinguishes between users by leveraging behavioral biometrics that unobtrusively capture a user's unique computing behavior, such as how they type on keyboards or how they move the mouse. The proposed software product packages state-of-the-art authentication algorithms so that existing software applications can access them via API calls. In addition, end users can be provided with options to fully control their own biometric data and ensure full privacy protection. The technological implementation of the proposed approach uses JavaScript in the web browsers and integrates with legacy applications at the server end.

Upon the completion of the initial customer discovery during I-Corps training, our main conclusion has been that the introduction of products and services based on behavioral biometrics is commercially highly promising, and thus should be continuously explored. Consistent with this conclusion, the PI has filed a U.S. patent application based on their novel techniques in keystroke dynamics-based authentication. Furthermore, the PI's institution has entered into a license agreement with a software company that is to integrate the PI's technology into their products and market the technology to their existing customer base. This partnership is expected to provide the critical insights needed by the PI to further validate the market acceptance of the proposed innovation.
